conclusion: Sphere A is stationary on the inclined plane with zero tension in the wire.
Sphere A is on an inclined plane, and sphere B is to the right of sphere A at the same height.
The forces acting on sphere A are weight (mg) acting downward, normal force (N) perpendicular to the inclined plane, and electrostatic repulsive force (F_e) from sphere B.
The electrostatic force between point charges is F_e = k(q^2/d^2), acting along the line connecting the centers of A and B.
Since both spheres are at the same height, the electrostatic force acts horizontally to the right.
Decompose the horizontal electrostatic force into components: parallel to incline (F_e cosθ) and perpendicular to incline (F_e sinθ).
Decompose the weight into components: parallel to incline (mg sinθ) and perpendicular to incline (mg cosθ).
For sphere A to be stationary, forces parallel to the incline must balance: F_e cosθ = mg sinθ.
For sphere A to be stationary, forces perpendicular to the incline must balance: N - F_e sinθ - mg cosθ = 0.
From the first equilibrium equation, k(q^2/d^2) cosθ = mg sinθ.
Rearranging to isolate q/d: k(q^2/d^2) = mg tanθ.
Taking the square root of both sides gives q/d = sqrt(mg tanθ/k).
The final answer for the ratio q/d is sqrt(mg tanθ/k).
